comments.commentBody: Isn't it peculiar to see a representative of each of the three remaining undefeated teams on the list?  It's as if someone is saying, "oh, you have to have someone from that team because they are doing so good".  Sometimes a team's performance is because of several really good players and not one great player.  Don't forget the Heisman is for the best individual player (see voting rules).  For example, Collin Klein's stats, relatively speaking, are not that impressive.  (There are currently at least three dozen QBs with more passing yards.)  I hope the writers get it right this year and look at all the top players regardless of where there team is ranked.

We'll still have to defend them, anyway.  A number of our allies have virtually no oil of their own, and world oil demand is projected to rise over the next 20-30 years, probably longer.  Moreover, oil field development is largely in the hands of private companies, whose owners may or may not want to develop the fields soon.  Moreover, the large oil companies are international; some of them don't seem to be  interested whether the US is energy independent or not.

Thank you james.jordan for your very realistic analysis of our predicament.  All this crowing about our energy independence is based upon the reliance upon the most poisonous and destructive practices that utilize the most desperate extraction methods involving massive displacement of entire ecosystems and the use of huge amounts of water and poisonous chemicals, for starters.  The fossil fuel corporations have shown repeatedly that they could care less about the living systems of the planet, an only further feeding their already bloated (off shore) bank accounts.  Apparently, in spite of all the evidence of imminent destruction of any future sustainability, these greedsters will persist with their ultimate ripoff of the earth and much of the life on it.
On the other hand, it's also time for the media to take the Dalai Lama to task for keeping his silence on this issue.

Let's not get to a point where you need to be poor before we think you are qualified to hold office. As Tevia in Fiddler on the Roof said,

"Dear God, you made many, many poor people. I realize, of course, that it's no shame to be poor. But it's no great honor either!

So, what would have been so terrible if I had a small fortune?"
Yes, $200,000. http://taxfoundation.org/blog/250000-threshold-how-does-it-work "...and single taxpayers making over $200,000"
Why don't you pay it and stop asking for someone else to?  Want to talk fair?  A Flat tax where everyone pays the same percent would fit the definition of "fair"

I have mixed feelings about Warren. On the one hand, she *might* hold Wall Street insiders accountable for some of their abuses. If so, I'll be impressed.

But her cynical use of fraudulent American Indian status to milk the "diversity" benefits, and her persistent refusal to come clean about it, leave a permanent shadow on her reputation. Just because the Times won't mention it doesn't mean that people don't know about it.

History is filled with politicians who turned out to be wolves in sheep's clothing. Is Warren a true crusader, or a bankruptcy lawyer on the make? Time will tell.

What going over the 'fiscal cliff' would mean....reminds me of what president Bush said to get TARP passed:

"The government's top economic experts warn that without immediate action by congress America could slip into a financial panic and a destructive scenario would unfold.
More banks could fail including some in your community.
The stock market would drop even more which would reduce the value of your retirement account.
The value of your home could plummet.
Foreclosures would rise dramatically.
And if you own a business or a farm you would find it harder and more expensive to get credit.
More businesses would close their doors and millions of Americans can lose their jobs.
Even if you have good credit history it would be more difficult to get the loans you need to buy a car or send your children to college.
And ultimately our country could experience a long and painful recession.
Fellow citizens we must not let this happen."

Rampell asserts: “lots of young Americans are finally moving out of their parents’ basements and forming their own households now that the economy is picking up.”

Is the economy really picking up… or is her assertion mere MSM rhetoric?

Since 2008-2009 half of college graduates are still unemployed. Many of those that are employed are working in low-paying service industry jobs not related to their degreed specialty(s). Some of this group are also “underemployed”, working as “self-contractors”, with no benefits, etc.

This also applies to many people that are older than college gratuates. And there is still at least 24 million adult Americans unemployed. Twice that amount may be working in jobs where they’re earning anywhere from 33% less to 66% less than they were formerly making… but they classify in the DOL stats as “employed”.

Various economic think-tanks have cited the “real” unemployment stats being 14%-20%.

Rampell ends her take on the “economy is picking up” with “In 2007, 1.3 million unemployed adult children were living in their parents’ homes. This year, the total is about 2.5 million.”

In effect… that’s double than 5 years ago. How does that square with the “economy picking up”?

Yet another perfect example of why we need the Consumer  Financial Protection Bureau so desperately.  I hope this issue is high on their to-do list!  It's small businesses' only hope for transparency.

The reaction of suppliers and consumers would have naturally caused prices to rise to equilibrium levels. When prices are low, quantity demanded is greater than quantity supplied (causing a shortage). Economically speaking, it would make sense for suppliers to raise their prices because there are too many buyers chasing too few goods. Raising prices would not cause a loss in sales.

You say that education increases earnings. That is not necessarily cause and effect. Educated people earn more, but that may be because (aside from vocational credentials like medicine and law) whatever it is that makes them persist in school also, independently, contributes to success in the job market.

The push to get more people through the educational system has diluted the content of education in order to avoid failing or discouraging the less motivated and less talented. It may be that the average high school diplomate, or college graduate, today has weaker and less economically valuable skills than the person with the same credential a generation ago.

When I see the ignorance and misuse of vocabulary in articles in our most prestigious newspapers (NYT and WSJ) I ask why they cannot hire people who are more literate in their native language. The general level of literacy must have gone down. The courses at my university have certainly been "dumbed down", and surveys have shown that students study much less than a generation ago. It shows. Despite their credentials, our graduates do not have the thinking and quantitative skills that would make them productive employees, and that would make their employers profitable enough to pay better wages.

I do not necessarily agree with the general idea of allowing gasoline to be more accessible/available for the more wealthy individuals. However, when taking into consideration the fact that doing so would allow for more efficient distribution of a limited resource that, in turn, would allow for people to spend their time doing other things rather than waiting hopelessly in a line, this almost seems appropriate.

Only somebody living in complete denial of reality-- aka, a modern era Republican-- could spin the truth that "oil production on federal lands has been dramatically expanded" into the Big Lie that "oil production on federal lands has been drastically curtailed."

I suggest that you borrow some money to complete your education sooner.

By delaying the launching of your nursing career, you are losing months and years of good income, dollars that can never, ever be made up.

It's like saying, "I'll give up $90,000 in income so that I don't have to borrow $20,000".

Think about it. Don't let your ideal become a ball and chain.

@MK: yes Luboman's solution would work. The "unanticipated consequence" presented is the reason why student loans were made non-dischargeable and has proven to be a government overreaction to a micro-percentage of doctors abusing the system (fraud laws exist to handle these statistical anomalies).

Further, credit card users can take out large loans, discharge in bankruptcy, and rebuild their credit.

Gamblers can take out large loans, discharge in bankruptcy, and rebuild their credit.

Drug dealers can take out large loans, discharge in bankruptcy, and rebuild their credit.

Why are credit card users, gamblers, and drug dealers protected by bankruptcy laws but students (and their co-signing parents) are not?

The explosion of tuition outpacing inflation by 3 to 1 began when bankruptcy protection was eliminated for student loans. It's not a coincidence. Luboman presents a solution where education costs would come way down allowing the system to work as it should.

Wouldn't it be nice if, for once, they would do a story about people like you?  There are so many articles, it seems, about folks like these who are in dire situations, and I think it may distort people's perception of the magnitude of the problem.
Bravo! I would much rather read your story than the ones in the article.

To Danni- here's the background on this family:
The public schools here are appalling. The son's disability, decent grades early on, good attitude and parents ability to pay part, qualified him for a partial scholarship at this gang-free private school, which my children also attended, and which I was unimpressed with- primarily because so much of it appeared to be a racket- from the gouging on text books and uniforms to the insistence that every kid apply to college regardless of desire, ability, resources.
I never said anywhere in my post that these people bear no responsibility. They wanted him in a safe environment, so they kept him in this "college prep." What I did say was, there was an unethical, high-pressured sales team all around them. Given that this highschool bars students from graduation unless they have at least 1 college acceptance, and given that every other child is also sucked into the college application maelstrom, it's difficult to not take part even if u are worldly enough to know u shouldn't.
These folks were sold a bill of goods, told this degree wud be life-changing for the child and the family. Yes they could have resisted the pitch and proceeded directly to community college but perhaps the parents were unable to judge their child objectively. Guidance Dept. however knew full well the boy's limits. That they deliberately steered the family into a scenario in which he had no chance of succeeding was not only hurtful for him but seems criminal.
"Very lucky"?  Where do you read that, @democrazy?  It all sounds like sound, prudent planning to me.

Suzanne - I wish I could take your post and plaster it across every college application in the US. I was lucky that my parents could afford to send me to an Ivy League college with minimal debt 15 yrs ago. However, after 4 years of medical school, 6 years of residency and 0.5 years of fellowship, my alma mater is an interesting factoid of my life, but not much more than that. My much younger sister is applying to college now, our parents are significantly older and with less earning power, and I've told her time and again it doesn't really matter where you go to college, as long as you avoid the trap of insane debt, pick a major with proven earning potential, and work hard wherever you go. The farther you get from college, the more you realize that the name of your college simply isn't critical enough to risk your financial future and that of your parents.

Don't get me wrong, there's intrinsic value in preserving and teaching liberal arts. It would be a terrible shame to lose knowledge for practicality. However, there's a reason I majored in biology and not linguistics, as much as I loved the latter subject. I ran into my favorite linguistics teacher my sophomore year, and what was this Ivy League professor who knew 15 languages doing? He'd resigned and begun working for the local pharmaceutical company as an English advisor to foreign employees. If college were free, by all means major in Russian lit, but if you're taking on debt, you have to be practical.

Remember the advice Mittwit Romney offered a group of college students this past April: If you want to get an education or start a business, borrow money from your parents.

Romney, a wealthy former investment banker who has struggled to soften his image as a member of America’s super elite, was discussing ways of achieving the American dream at Otterbein University. He said, “We've always encouraged young people: Take a shot, go for it. Take a risk. Get the education. Borrow money if you have to from your parents. Start a business.”

Is it any wonder that he lost the election? He simply has no clue as to how the other 99% live day-to-day.

I think that sweet55's point was that that democratic elections do not always yield happy results. As Winston Churchill once said "Democracy is the absolute worst form of government, except for all of the others".
Thanks for the updates -- priceless.  It was ever thus.

How are you so sure that, indeed, there was no crime ever committed by anyone when you know not a single shred of fact, circumstance, or even a post-facto cover-up by Obama Administration until the election was over? I should like to remind you that Nixon wasn't found guilty on day one of the breaking news that there was a "petty burglary" in Watergate.
In the military, infidelity is a crime.  If Petreaus is 'above the law', then he should change the law so that Privates aren't held to a higher standard than Generals.

The FBI agent who initiated this investigation at the request of the woman who was receiving the harassing emails, is himself now under investigation. It's been reported that he sent shirtless pictures of himself to that same woman and may have had political motives in making the investigation public. I'm not kidding.

Members of the Congressional committee that have oversight over the CIA think they also have a story to tell because the FBI didn't report Patraeus' infidelity quickly enough - Senator Diane Feinstein wants us to know she's launching an investigation about the Patraeus affair, too. Again, not kidding.

This appears to be a very small story about people with very big egos. Unless someone is charged with a crime, I'm just not interested.
